question:
(a) Explain the term error of closure

(b) Highlight any four sources of error of closure in closed traverse survey

(c) Outline two meaures that could be taken to avoid an error of closure
answer:
(a) The term "Error of closure" is the failure of the end point of a closed traverse to fall exactly on the point of origin of the traverse. The error can only be known when the field details are plotted.

(b) Sources of error of closure:

(i) Inaccurate measurement of the sides.

(ii) Wrong bookings of bearing.

(iii) Taking wrong bearing

(iv) Inaccurate booking of all measurements

(v) Using faulty instrument.

(vi) Mistakes in actual plotting.

(vii) Possible effects on magnetic compass by magnetic material.

(c) Measures to avoid an error of closure:

(a) Cross-check the functionality of all instrument.

(b) Check the measurement on the plan plotted.

(c) Take backward bearing as well as on bearing to check errors in measurement of bearing.

(d) Check presence of magnetic materials on and around the user.

question:
(a) if the time in London is 08.00 hours GMT and the local time in Addis Ababa is 12.00 noon on what longitude ts Addis Ababa?

(b) Write explanatory notes on the following:
(i) Time zones; (ii) Standard Times; (iii) International Dateline
answer:
(a) Difference in time between London 08 hours GMT and Addis Ababa 12.00 noon = 4 hours. The earth rotate through 1° in 4 minutes or through 15° in 1 hour. The difference in longitude = 4hrs x 15° = 60° From the question, time in Addis Ababa is ahead of GMT. Therefore, Addis Ababa is East of the Greenwich Meridian (GMT) located on longitude 60°E.

(b)(i) TIME ZONES:- The world is splitted into 24 time zones. Each cover 15° of longitude. The difference between 2 successive zones is one hour. All places located on the same time zone have the same time. For every 15° movement across the longitude West of the GMT an hour is always lost while to the east an hour is gained.

(ii) STANDARD TIME:- Is the generally adopted time from the central meridian of a Time Zone. It is often set to avoid confusion in local time between one town and the other in the same country. Standard Time spans with 15° of longitude. GMT is a standard time for all the world time zones.

(iii) INTERNATIONAL DATE LINE:- It is longitude 180° East and West of the Greenwich meridian. It is zigzag in structure to avoid cutting across islands. Date changes by one day when crossed east or west. Crossing to the east, gain a day while crossing to the West, a day is lost.

question:
(a) State any four factors that determine the temperature of a place

(b) (i) List the two climatic elements used as the basis of Koppen's classification
(ii) Identify the main climatic groups in Koppen's climatic classification
answer:
(a) FACTORS THAT DETERMINE THE TEMPERATURE OF A PLACE.

(i) LATITUDE:- Tropical latitudes generally are hotter than temperate latitudes because the sun's altitude is generally high in the tropics and lower in the temperate. Similarly, temperate latitude are warmer than polar latitudes.

(ii) ALTITUDE:- Places nearer the earth's surface are warmer than those at higher altitude. Temperature decreases with increasing height above sea-level. The late of decrease in temperature is 0.6°C with an ascent of 100m above sea-level. Example: Mount Kilimanjaro (about 6000m) although close to the Equator is always snow capped, Jos Plateau and the Guinea Highland in West Africa are good examples.

(iii) DISTANCE FROM THE SEA:- Land surfaces heat and cool faster than sea surfaces. The sea warms coastal regions in winter but cools them in summer. In summer, land surfaces are warmer than sea surfaces and the air over the land, therefore, is warmer than the one over the sea which make coastal regions to be cooler than inland.

(iv) PREVAILING WINDS:- Winds affect temperature by transporting their heat or coldness into adjacent regions. On-shore Westerlies convey much tropical warm air to temperate coasts especially in winter. In Britain and Norway Westerlies tend to be cool winds in summer and warm variable in moderating the climate. Local winds such as Fohn, Chinook, Sirocco, Mistral also produce marked changes in temperature. The North-East trade wind from the Sahara lowers the night and morning temperatures of the Sahel region.

(v) OCEAN CURRENTS:- Warm ocean currents tend to have increased temperature. Cold currents tend to have a reducti3n in temperature. Ocean currents such as the Gulf steams or the North Atlantic Drift warm the coastal district', Western Europe and by so doing keep their coasts ice - free.

(vi) CLOUD OVER:- This acts as blanket, reducing the amount of radiation reaching the earth. Leads to lowering of temperature.

(b)(i) TWO CLIMATIC ELEMENTS USED AS BASIS OF KOPPEN'S CLASSIFICATION.
(i) Tempc.rature.
(ii) Precipitation / rainfall.

(ii) KOPPENS CLIMATIC GROUPS
A = Tropical rain climates
B = Dry climates.
C = Warm temperature rainy or humid meso-thermal climate.
D = Cool temperate or micro thermal climate.
E = Polar or ice climate
